reviewText: Alright, seeing a lot of negativity around this movie, which is too bad.  It's going to turn a lot of people off from watching it.  I rented this not expecting much and I was surprised to find myself laughing my @$$ off shortly after it started.  I'd place this movie up there with Talladega Nights and Blades of Glory.  The only thing missing is Will Ferrell, but that's alright.  I think people may be taking this movie too seriously.  I think that this movie pokes a lot of fun at itself, and there are some awful scenes to back that up (the whole Flashdance thing).  You'll either find these scenes hysterical or horrible.  It all depends on your sense of humor and the mood you're in.  If your dog died this morning, yeah, you'll probably hate it.  If you enjoyed Blades of Glory (and yes, I know a lot of people didn't), you'll probably dig this.

reviewText: In the same vein as `Napoleon Dynamite' and, well, just about every Will Ferrell (or Adam Sandler or Jack Black) movie out there, `Hot Rod' is a mash up of funny, awkward and absurd.  Unlike those Ferrell movies (or at least most of the Ferrell movies), `Hot Rod' doesn't all come together.  It has its moments; and when it is funny it is REALLY funny; but those moments are far and few in between.This is kind of sad, because Andy Samberg is better than this (just youtube him, he is hysterical).The film tells the story of Rod, a man-boy living at home with his mother, step-father and step-brother.  Rod's father died in a horrible stunt accident, and so he spends his days trying to emulate his father by attempting stunts he is too stupid to actually complete.  When his cruel and harsh step-father winds up terminally ill and in need of a `conveniently priced' heart operation, Rod decides to raise the money for the operation by performing a HUGE stunt.He wants to save his life so he can beat him to death.Andy has great comedic timing, and he uses that to save a lot of this films more ridiculous moments, but even he can't create funny out of overkill, and the film does suffer from that in many places.  Like I said, when it is funny it is really funny (the stunts are great, and that "I like to party" scene is priceless) but it is often more awkward and absurd, two elements that only work when the funny is sprinkled in.Samberg has a slew of talented comedians (or at least the new breed of comedian) backing him up here, and all of them lend to the comedic atmosphere.  Jorma Taccone is subtle in his comedy and that works to offset Samberg's abrasiveness.  Bill Hader is a comedian I don't love despite his glaring fan base, but he has his moments here.  Danny McBride usually gets on my nerves, but he sells it here and delivers some of the films best moments.  Isla Fisher is brilliant and I will watch her in anything, seriously.  Here she is gorgeous (ugh, she is so hot) and funny and charming and sweet and totally above this movie.  Sissy Spacek and Ian McShane were odd stars for this vehicle, but they both do a great job (especially McShane).I won't `recommend' this movie, because there is a lot better out there, but I will say that it is not a complete loss.  I will recommend Samberg's viral videos on youtube though, since they are all great.  Just look at `Lazy Sunday' or the hilarious `I Threw it on the Ground'.  Seriously, he is so much better than this movie.
summary: Not so hot; more like luke-warm...

reviewText: "Hot Rod" is an outstanding study of the modern comedic tendencies of off the wall fun.  Taking an "Anchorman" type humorous approach with a dash of "Napoleon Dynamite", the comedy cracks some bizarre jokes and hilarious sight gags that will have fans of silly comedies rolling in the aisles.  It's been a while since I laughed so much at one movie.  I rarely watch movies over again in the same day.  "Hot Rod" was one of those movies.Silly stunts, wacky sight gags, a dash of '80's music, and Ebenezer Scrooge (yes, that Ebenezer Scrooge), "Hot Rod" will keep you laughing, guaranteed...I'm Bowie, and I party...
summary: Fans of silly fun look no further...
Title: N/A

reviewText: Meet Rod. Rod's a stuntman. Rod also hates his step father.When Rod learns his nemisis--his step father, Frank--is dying but their insurance won't cover the heart transplant he needs to live, he hatches a plan to save Frank...so he can beat him up.There's a fairly familiar trend with comedies in recent memory where the first half is hilarious and then the second half fails to measure up. Not so with Hot Rod. From beginning to end, I haven't laughed as hard and long as I did while watching Hot Rod in an extremely long time. Just when you think the downfall is about to begin something completely off the wall happens that keeps you laughing.Cast to perfection, Hot Rod proves that comedies can be nonstop funny and still attain some sort of story. At the very heart of this film you have a guy doing whatever he can to save his step father's life, all while pursuing his dream of being a stuntman to keep his dead father's memory alive. But that's just a side note. I completely expected this movie to be unbelievably funny yet was ready to be let down, Hot Rod promises comedy and delivers tenfold. Extremely highly recommended.By the way, this movie actually has possibly the funniest moment I've ever seen in the form of Rod "punch dancing" in a secluded wooded area and turns into a very long fall down a cliff...priceless.
summary: I'm kidding, I heard you, that was just really mean.

reviewText: The small budget '07 film `Hot Rod' is a zany, unpretentious, Indie looking production that you will either find absolutely hilarious or leave you wondering "what in the world was that all about?"  My initial reaction put me in the "what was that all about" camp however as I began to reflect back on some of the parodies and dialogue I found myself chuckling over what I had missed during my viewing of this film.Andy Samberg and Bill Hader are hilarious, Isla Fisher is adorable and the rest of the cast is rock solid. Lots of inane comedy value to be had by one and all, just please don't attempt any of the stunts you will view on your own. Leave them to the real stuntmen out there.

reviewText: I read quite a few of the reviews of this film before watching it. Calling it stupid and silly is pointless.  In fact, those kinds of remarks are actually nice things to say about the movie.So, what we have here is a silly, off-beat, goofy comedy.  I gave it four stars for how well I think the movie holds up in that particular genre.  It is a really entertaining movie that has plenty of stupidity, which it is supposed to have.

reviewText: Hot Rod marks one of the first films to feature the new generation of Saturday Night Live members with Andy Samberg and Bill Hader. It's standard practice that SNL has become a launching pad for a movie career. Do Samberg and Hader have what it takes to make that jump from the small screen to the big one? If you putFootloose (Special Collector's Edition),Napoleon Dynamite - Like, the Best Special Edition Ever!, andNacho Libre (Special Collector's Edition)into a blender, Hot Rod would be the martini you would get.Andy Samberg plays the eternal optimist with zero talent and tons of ambition. He's the Ed Wood of the stuntmen world. He commits himself completely to the role and is likable enough. Isla Fisher is absolutely adorable as the film's love interest and lights up the screen with her engaging smile infectious energy.Hot Rod follows the tried and true formula of the inept underdog who doggedly pursues his goal despite a lack of any kind of talent. However, this film has a very off-kilter, staccato rhythm all its own, reminiscent of Napoleon Dynamite, that is surprisingly refreshing.The film features unusual exchanges between characters, like when Rod asks Denise, who would win a fight: a grilled cheese sandwich or a taco, to which she replies, "In a fair fight or prison rules?" This should give you an idea of what kind of film this is. To further throw you off, the film's soundtrack is populated by 1970s prog rock, cheesy 1980s synth-pop and a scary abundance of music by Europe that makes you wonder just what year this film is set in.Hot Rod is not a gut-busting, laugh out loud funny film but funny in its own unassuming way. Just when you think this is going to be another tired, formulaic SNL film, it takes a hard left into strangeville. Hot Rod has a quirky, personal feel of an independent film and not a studio picture. It is one of those films completely misrepresented by its trailers but in a good way. It is a modest film with a lot of heart - much like its protagonist.There is an audio commentary by director Akiva Schaffer and actors Andy Samberg and Jorma Taccone. They mainly banter and crack jokes with Schaffer being the only one remotely trying to stay on topic. They ruthlessly make fun of each other which is pretty entertaining even if it feels like a series of in-jokes at times."Ancestors Protect Me: Behind the Scenes of Hot Rod" is a jokey take on the usual promotional featurette as cast and crew ham it up for the camera and poke fun at these kinds of extras.Also included are 13 deleted and extended scenes with optional commentary by Schaffer, Samberg and Taccone. They crack jokes about this footage and explain that it was cut because of time constraints.There is also an "Outtakes Reel" that is an odd collection of bits that aren't all that funny per se, but rather peculiar - kind of like the film itself."Kevin's Videos" are eight clips shot by Rod's step-brother Kevin that were glimpsed in excerpts in the film. These are funny "promos" and "training exercises" showing how inept Rod is at, well, anything physical. One promo has Rod admiring a jetski that's not his."Punch-Dance" takes a look at Rod's "inspiring" tribute to one of the dance sequences in Footloose with a shot-by-shot comparison that is quite funny."Home Video Footage of Orchestra Recording Session" is exactly what you get and that's it.Finally, there is a theatrical trailer.
summary: A modest film with a lot of heart...much like Rod himself.

reviewText: This movie had me laughing from start to finish. Why? It throws away a lot of typical comedic conventions, plays with pacing and brings irreverence to a whole new level.Wait, plays with pacing? Yes. Segues? gone. Leave the viewer waiting for more when all other movies would have taken the cheap laugh? borderline brilliant (in terms of comedy. This is NOT a brainy film).There's a different feel to this movie that I'm sure will leave some viewers behind...which may also explain its poor box office sales. But if you're up for the laughs in a comedy that does more than kick someone in the crotch and wait for high school boys to laugh, then this is it.All-in-all. Two thumbs up. Watch it with some friends and I dare you not to laugh till your stomach hurts.Parents: Outside of a brief drug reference (acid, plays almost no part in the film) and some occasional language, this movie wouldn't be too much for a young teen to handle.

reviewText: An overlooked bit of screwball comedy from the members of The Lonely Island and a few of their mid-2000 SNL cohorts. Andy Samberg grabs the lead as the titular Rod, a misguided but confident would-be stuntman whose efforts always climax in a spectacular disaster. Rod is about as one-dimensional as any recurring sketch comedy character, which is to say he's got one note to play and he milks it like a rancher with idle hands. Along for the ride, Bill Hader, Danny McBride (playing, surprise, another version of Kenny Powers), Ian McShane (grievously underused) and a white-hot Isla Fisher, are even narrower. After five minutes you'll know exactly how it's going to play out. This kind of movie isn't usually about character development, though, and as a playground for comedians to wear silly t-shirts and frequently cut away to questionably-related asides, it's suitable enough. Good for a few loud howls, but it lacks consistency, substance and identity. Its greatest sin is taking a decent gag and riding it wayyyy too long, a'la Family Guy's most indulgent moments. In short, it's precisely how the trailer makes it seem: really, really stupid. Points for an excellent butt rock / hair metal soundtrack, though.
summary: Funny But Light and Stretched, Samberg's Hot Rod is Undercooked

reviewText: In "Hot Rod", the character Denise answers the above question as follows: "Grilled cheese. But only in a fair fight. If it's prison rules, I'd take the taco." And that pretty much sums up the flavor of this odd, hilarious, and utterly absurd movie. For fans of slapstick comedy, this might be the greatest film in the history of American cinemaThe opening sequence of this movie perfectly sets the tone for what is to come over the next 90 minutes. Rod's disastrous, obscenely painful jump attempt is at once cringe-worthy and so funny that you might pull an oblique muscle from laughter. The following are but a few of the many, many ridiculously hilarious moments in "Hot Rod":Rod randomly pounding on an engine block with a hammer while wearing a yellow Hulkamania tank top and muttering, "funky fresh."Rod praying to his menegarie of spirit totems, including the eagle, fox, and bottlenose dolphin, before engaging in dangerous stunts.Rod bobsledding into a parked trailer at approximately sixty miles per hour, causing the glass to blow out and an enraged hillbilly to emerge.Danny McBride (BEFORE he was Danny McBride) doing "extreme hi-fiving" and belting out such gems as, "I been dinking green tea all goddamn DAY! Woo! ...You gonna bring the demons outta me!"Will Arnett, perfectly cast as the obnoxious boyfriend of Denise, driving his Corvette about and shouting his legendary line of, "Baaaaaaaaaabe!" and, "Yeah, we'll take three flaming Dr. Peppers."And let's not forget the legendary Ian McShane, who bravely reaches WAY outside his comfort zone to give what I would argue is the single greatest performance of his career. From busting heads with "Rhodesian fighting sticks" to tooling around in a sweat suit and a fly fishing hat while frequenting the movie theater in a wheelchair, this is his most bizarre and impressive role to date.Do you like to laugh? To smile? Are you not pretentious or uppity? Then watch "Hot Rod", and join your fellows in a raucous good time!
summary: "Who do you think would win in a fight between a grilled cheese sandwich and a taco?" -Rod

reviewText: I don't want to knock Andy Samberg....I like the guy.  He's a talented actor and I want to see more of him in comedy films.  So, I'm going to knock the film a little.There are moments in the film that are funny.  Most of it is slapstick.  But for me, Hot Rod is another example of a low ball movie that completely wastes the talent of the actors.  Another brilliant SNL actor, Bill Hader, co-stars and his value is diminished as well.  It's like the cast did everything they could to save the film but it just wasn't going to happen because the script needed to be trashed in the first place.  I call this situation, "sugaring the turd" because no matter how much sugar you pour on it, it still is going to taste like....you get the picture.I won't give spoilers.  The movie is worth a view.  Maybe it's me, I don't know, but this was a lackluster film with bright shining stars that in the end really suppressed the actors abilities.  I blame the director.

reviewText: Hot Rod is one of the funniest movies of 2007, but many of the critics are not on the same mindset as my self--when it comes to its good humor. Director Akiva Schaffer gives us that nostalgic look and feel of the 80's, when it comes to the set designs, costume design, and even the cinematography. Also it will remind the audience a lot of the "YouTube" generation of film making. This movie is a message in the bottle to those underdog 80's comedies when it comes to these characteristics.Rod Kimble (Andy Samberg [SNL star]) has wanted to be a stuntman like his deceased father who he believes worked for Evel Kenevel; as a successful stunt man because of the photograph that his mother kept for him. His stepfather Frank (Ian McShane) does not really think much of his pursuit to be a professional stunt man; he causes much grief for Rod. Therefore, Rod always wants to prove his manhood through their weekly sparring sessions, but unfortunately Frank humiliates every time.He comes up with a new stunt--after being humble by his stepfather again--which is to jump over the town's public pool and he shares this with Denise, his next door neighbor. His stunt ends in failure and soon afterwards, he goes home to see that his stepbrother Kevin (Jorma Taccone) is hugging his father. Rod learns that Frank is dying--because of his weak heart--and he has only six months to live. He is very upset because he was the last to find out; like always when it concerns family matters.Rod needs some time alone; he goes to the woods to get out his frustrations and while he is doing this, he accidentally falls down an embankment. When he stops falling, he notices a sign concerning information that will help Frank's weak heart. In a short while, he tells his stepbrother and his two friends Dave (Bill Hader) and Rico (Danny R. McBride) as well as Denise, that he is going to jump 15 buses to raise $50,000 for his Frank's surgery. As he is preparing for the stuns, he finds more truths about his life. Will he succeed with the aid of his friends?When viewing the preview to Hot Rod I told my partner that this film looks very similar to "Super Dave Osborne"--a stuntman--who performs extreme stunts, which gives the notion of slapstick humor because of the way he receives his injuries. Our director and Samberg also focus on the silly situational humor that we often found in this time period with such cult films as: Better Off Dead (1985) and One Crazy Summer (1986), starring John Cusack. What they do so effectively is that they give this impression by the way our main characters look, act, and as well as showing their personal surroundings; they blend the modern times with that of the past very effectively--that it will remind the audience of the Brady Bunch movie (1995).The writing was very good; the jokes were funny--not distasteful like recent comedies--and the stuns are much like those found in YouTube.com. In other words, the film has the nostalgia of the 80s.Permission granted because of the refreshing change from recent vulgar comedies--such as Knocked Up,  Norbit, or  Wild Hogs. Hot Rod has the nostalgia impression of the 80's comedy like Better Off Dead  and One Crazy Summer and with a touch of "YouTube" generation with the cinematography. This is cool humor from director Akiva Schaffer and Andy Samberg and one you must see.
summary: Hot Rod is one of the funniest movies of 2007-- with a touch of the You Tube generation of Film making

reviewText: Hot Rod is a movie that is meant to keep you laughing. It's not going to be serious, and when it does have it's serious moments, they last about 5 seconds. But it doesn't matter because Rod Kimble is not a serious guy, no matter how hard he tries. That's what makes the movie so great. He's a guy who just wants to kick his step-dad's ass, and he's got great friends who want to help him. At the same time he re-unites with the girl-next-door and a beautiful/goofy/adorable romance arises. I watch this movie when I want to feel good about life. It's a hilarious movie and it has a great soundtrack. I HIGHLY recommend buying Hot Rod and watching it at least a thousand times. At least.
summary: Hot Rod is meant to be FUNNY

reviewText: Many of the other reviews really catch the spirit of this film but since I watched it and it moved me, I felt obligated to comment. Please read my review with this in mind... this movie is not meant to be more than brain candy for pot heads. The fact that it finds ways to be more than this is a testimony to the actors, the script and the filming.Rod is a unique character, a 25 year old teenager with the mentality of a 10 year old. Following the dream of being like his dead stunt man father and trying the earn the respect of his step father... he is the quintessential moron complete with cape, moped and all. Surrounded by a crew of even more qualified and useless idiots he is the king of his teeny tiny narrow little world bestriding it like a colossus. The plot thickens when his step father is declared to be dying of a bad heart and Rod becomes determined to raise the money to save him so that he will still have a chance to beat him up and prove he is a man. The sub plot provides the romantic theme with the small town girl secretly having a crush on him, yet caught up with the big town boyfriend, complete with little red corvette.This movie, whether it means to or not has all of the ingredients of the fairytale complete with symbolism. The supporting cast is fantastic in their roles... with each providing an opportunity to give you a chuckle. The theme of becoming a man in an age of indifference is not missed despite the absolutely ridiculous plot. In fact it does a surprisingly good job of telling that story and validating it... more so than many other movies that I have seen whose express role was exactly that.The humour is that of Dumb and Dumber or Napoleon Dynamite but the symbolic theme ranks up there with Joe Vs the Volcano (without all of the visual attributes). If you have a relatively loose ability to see the humour in life with or without the use of drugs, this movie will not disappoint. If you have high standards for story lines, plots, etc... and lost your sense of humour around the time that the PC became prevalent in society... this movie will escape you and you will feel as if you slipped into the twilight zone. As one reviewer says... you either get it or you don't. Personally I found some gems of truth in this, especially since I was raised by a step father... a reality that many young men face in this day and age. Ian McShane was perfect as the highly potent step father and Bill Hader Danny McBride and Jorma Taccome as his 'crew' all had singular moments that will elicit light chuckles to out right laughs. Andy Samberg as Rod also has some truly funny moments when he flies off the handle in his teen tirades... he is the perfect idiot hero.Rated PG-13 for some suggestive images and innuendo along with some mild language... this movie would be good for a few beers and a few laughs with the guys. Don't bother watching this with your girlfriend... they would find it childish and while the story might eventually get their attention... it is likely they will not thank you for the time wasted. Of course there are some females out there that enjoy childish humour with a deeper underlying theme but I have not met many :)Open your mind... get in touch with your inner child... leave your brains at the door and enjoy!

reviewText: This movie is completely baffling, incredibly stupid, and side-splittingly hilarious at the same itme.  Every stupid movie cliché is present (except the slow clap), and just when you get comfortable with the cinema norm, assuming and predicting the next scene, everything is flipped on its head, with all sorts of "Huh?"-moments throughout.To me it seems like a sequel to Napolean Dynamite (there's even a major character named Rico for goodness sakes!), with the same spastic action and filming techniques, where one scene has nothing to do with the other, but there is nonetheless comic cohesion.  It's complete randomness that makes it enjoyable.Perhaps the greatest part of the movie is the not-so-subtle parody of Footloose, with Rod (Andy Samberg) imitating the "I'm so mad I gotta dance" scene.  It's simply brilliant, and just as stupid as the original.The actual story is nearly inconsequential, as Rod - a life long stuntman in his father's mold - attempts to gain enough money with his crew, starring the beautiful Isla Fisher, to pay for his step-father's heart transplant.  And the only reason he's raising the money, and risking his life on lethally dangerous stunts, is to nurse his condescending step-father back to health so that he can beat him up in a fist-fight, thereby earning respect and the honor of being called a man.I will be completely shocked if this doesn't turn into a cult classic.
summary: I don't know if it's incredibly funny or incredibly stupid

reviewText: Very Napoleon Dynamite-ish in its celebration of nerds uniting and being themselves, Hot Rod has more laugh-out-loud moments peppered with very sly humor than Napoleon Dynamite.The parts that were laugh out loud funny were Rod's dance in the woods, the street luge scene, the cool beans rap, the scene where the crew walks down the street with the gathering crowd (hilarious every time I see it), every jump or stunt Rod does and every interaction between Rod and his step dad, of which there are many. There are several little jokes that are easy to miss ("This thing's being bounced around the web like a beach ball at a Nickelback concert"), some stuff that is over the top dramedy ("Babe! No! Babe, no!") and some that is terrifically tongue-in-cheek ("They've done it! They've raised $50,000 for Frank's conveniently priced surgery!")This is not a four-star movie because of the plot, message or character development; it's four stars because it knows what it wants to be and does a good job living up to it. If you go in expecting "Casablanca" you are going to be disappointed. If you go in thinking, "I hope this is better than Coneheads," chances are you'll like it.
summary: WHy am I saying WHat WHat WHay?

reviewText: Not long ago I wrote a review for the funny and creative Mike Judge film,Idiocracy.  Although I found it's seething commentary agreeable, I must admit that just because the film may be right, it does not suddenly make me any less vulnerable to finding humor in any of the many silly and cheap gags that persist in the undeniably hilarious Andy Samberg feature film debut, Hot Rod.  Stupidity is was it is and to me at least, what it is, at times, is comedy gold.Rod (Samberg) is a grown man who lives with his mother, his step brother, and his step father.  He longs to earn the respect of his step father by defeating him in hand-to-hand combat.  Rod, like his late father was assumed to be, is a stuntman.  He wears a silly outfit and a phony mustache to extenuate his showmanship.  His stunts are silly dramatic jumps he does on his moped.  So far it sounds like a weak story setting the stage for a fictionalized version of the shenanigans one may see on Jackass.  It is not far from that of course.  Rod's step father has a bad heart and his insurance company won't cover his high risk heart operation.  No matter, because Rod is going to raise the money by jumping seven buses so he can save his step father and subsequently defeat him in hand-to-hand combat, and therefore become a man.  No, it is not an existential film, nor is it a sharp commentary against the crumbled American health care system.  It is just a vehicle to make teenage potheads laugh, and although I'm not a teenage pothead myself I still laughed...loudly, and often.Sometimes, I prefer my comedy straight forward and without any other obvious motives.  I like to have something in the background that makes me laugh without being attached to the film.  I like thethree stooges. I lovedMonty Python and the Holy Grail.  I like someZucker moviesand I like someFarrelly movies. I lovedRon Burgundy, andBilly Madisonmakes me laugh harder every single time I see it.  I even liked Norm MacDonald inDirty WorkandChris Farley's brand of humor is exactly the brand for me.  If you think most of the above is silly and not funny to you then I suggest you pass on Hot Rod.It's important to note that Hot Rod is more derivative then most similar comedies.  It is a lot of the same silly humor recycled or used with an even more extreme spin.  It pulls some punches in spots where I would've hoped for more.  It is also only PG-13 and I must admit that sometimes I prefer my humor a bit dirtier.  Either way, it isn't a real movie per se and I would never give a movie created in this mold a perfect rating no matter how much it made me laugh.  So Hot Rod doesn't get a whole-hearted recommendation as it is fundamentally lacking some key elements it needs to tell an actual story, but if you like this kind of thing and want a good laugh then I'd strongly suggest you pick it up.
Title: N/A

reviewText: We have watched so many SNL comics either rise or fall when they move to the giant screen.With a script that was written by Pam Brady of SOUTH PARK MOVIE fame, I had anticipated something hopefully funny,bigger and longer than what I had seen on the trailers. It didn't happen.My opinion here is that the script is so not funny especially since it is mostly involved with Andy Samburg as Rod, training for the stunt of clearing fifteen school buses that will raise money to help his sick stepfather.Sorry, but this is really boring as humorless sight gags and really bad plot elements destroy anything that Samburg could do to make this material funny.If you liked NAPOLEON DYNAMITE, which this film so reminds me of, then I doubt you will like HOT ROD.Sorry.

reviewText: I remember seeing the trailer for Hot Rod on a DVD that I had either purchased or rented. I remember thinking to myself "oh boy, another crapfest". It fairs better than a SD DVD release, but not by much. Definitely nothing to write home about.AudioI'm not much of an audiophile, but I have to say I was pretty impressed with the Dolby TrueHD soundtrack throughout the film. The music was mixed into the soundtrack nicely and the dialogue was done very well too.I would recommend Hot Rod for a definite rental for most. I myself am very happy with my purchase.

reviewText: I watched "Hot Rod" the day after Evel Knievel passed away, but since I spent an afternoon my first semester of college crammed into a dorm lobby with dozens of others in the vain hope that the television set would magically pick up whatever was airing the daredevil's attempt to jump the Snake River Canyon in a rocket sled that really did not qualify as a motorcycle that connection was inevitable.  So when Knievel was mentioned by name and showed up in an autographed photograph along with the title's character dearly departed father (irony abounds) it was as it should be in a film about a young man's whose big dream is to jump a motor scooter over 15 buses.  However, if you were placing a bet on the destiny of Rod Kimble (Andy Samberg), it would be that he is either going to end up in the hospital or on an episode of "Jackass" (or both).Rod has dreamed of being a stuntman just like his dear old dad for most of his life, and he has been learning the trade on his own with the help of his personal (wrecking) crew, which consists of his half-brother Kevin (Jorma Taccone) and his best buds Dave (Bill Hader) and Rico (Danny R. McBride).  Rob's stepfather Frank Powell (Ian McShane), has defeated Rob at every test of manhood the two of them can devise.  Then it turns out that Frank needs a heart transplant; without it, Rob will never be able to beat this step-dad and earn the guy's respect.  Rob's daredevil activities become the means towards the goal of getting the $50,000 Frank needs for a new heart (pretend that is all it costs, that hospitals make you pay up front, etc.).  Plus, all these efforts might serve to impress Denise (Isla Fisher), the girl of Rob's dreams.  She is dating a total jerk (Will Arnett), so Rob's chances are pretty good.  Actually, they are way better than they are that he is going to be able to jump 15 buses with a moped.This 2007 summer comedy is pleasant enough, mainly because Samberg's Rob is a nice guy.  His problem is simply that he does not know his limitations and is running (or riding) full-speed towards disaster.  This compares quite favorably to most of the first movies made by "Saturday Night Live" cast members when they got a chance to be stars (e.g, Molly Shannon in "Superstar," Will Ferrell and Chris Kattan in "A Night at the Roxbury," Rob Schneider in "Deuce Bigalow: Male Gigolo").  Like Adam Sandler in "Billy Madison," Samberg is helped by the fact he is not saddled with a "SNL" character for his first starring role (except for Wayne and Garth, how many of them that go to the big screen are all that loveable?).  Not everything here works (the scene where Rod decides to pronounce all "wh" words as "hw" is an odd insert into the proceedings), but in the end, I round up on "Hot Rod" because of the stirring scene when Rod walks down the street to his destiny while the inspirational power chords rev up in the background.  Things do not go quite as planned and for me it was by far the biggest laugh in the film.  Earlier in the film there is a take off on the scene in "Footloose" where Kevin Beacon dances by himself, with Rod finding his quiet place out in the forest that had its moments as well.  I will probably never watch this movie again, but it was fun to watch once and it was certainly nice to watch it today.
summary: Andy Samberg avoids crashing and burning in his first feature comedy

reviewText: Every inch of this movie is hilarious! Great performances by the entire cast, very funny special features and a fresh take on "stupid humor".On the "laugh out loud funny" commentary track(don't pass it by!) we learn that this movie was originally going to star Will Ferrel, but I'm glad he dropped out because Old Man Ferrel's got nothing on the new generation!Like Napoleon Dynamite meets Evil Knievel, this saga of an emotionally stunted (get it?) stunt man Rod Kimble and his crew's goal to raise money for his stepfather's life-saving operation explodes with unexpected laughs stemming from awkward attempts to pick up girls, endurance training and sibling relationships.The supporting cast (especially Danny McBride) really elevate the humor with their quirky character moments.  Don't get me wrong, this is a stupid movie, but it deserves much more attention than it got upon its release.  Check it out and get ready to laugh, Honchos.

Title: N/A

reviewText: After losing his father, a so-called "stuntman", to an accident a while back, son Rod Kimble (Andy Samberg) has been forced to put up with abuse from his mother's (Sissy Spacek) new beau, Frank (Ian McShane). When Frank suffers from heart problems, and $50,000 is needed for a new heart transplant, Rod assembles his friends (Bill Hader, Danny R. McBride, Jorma Taccone) and his long-time crush Denise (Isla Fisher) to prepare for a stunt jump that could net him the money needed. After that, Rod vows to get back at Frank."SNL" newcomer Andy Samberg makes the jump to the big screen in his first leading role. Probably well known for a variety of pre-recorded shorts and music video parodies that keep YouTube online, Samberg may not reach the heights of Will Ferrell or Adam Sandler. And I wish that I enjoyed "Hot Rod" more than I should've, because it seems like Samberg's Lonely Island frontman Akiva Schaffer is trying really hard to give his targeted audience - college students, mostly - a slam-bang time. But there's enough charm in the film that keeps it from slipping into meandering territory.With additional production from Andy's head cheese over at 30 Rock, Lorne Michaels, "Hot Rod" makes it clear: it's a crazy comedy that reaches for Adam Sandler-esque heights (think "Little Nicky" lite). Whether Rod is suffering an absurdly long fall down a cliff, forced to watch various clips of dog sex (which gets too much attention than it deserves, though I belly-laughed a bit), gets hit by a mini-van, raps with his brother with the contant use of the term "cool beans", or has to put up with his ill stepfather's abuse, this film goes for broad laughs. Aside from the tepid sentiment (it isn't as whacked out or shallow as "Kickin' It Old Skool"), Samberg's hilarious attempts at overacting are often funny.Probably one of the reasons why "Hot Rod" tries too hard at being funny are the overuse of adlibs. Often times it works in movies, such as "Artie Lange's Beer League" or from the Adam McKay/Judd Apatow films. The film often puts too much effort forcing its performers too improv a couple lines, repeat offenders include Bill Hader (I'll admit, he has a couple screamers, but he often overcompensates his lack of deserved screen time by hamming it up with ad-libbed wisecracks) and fellow "LI" member Joram Taccone as Rod's stepbro, causing the film to wink too much at the audience. The performers are relaxed, but it takes more than on-the-fly one-liners to make that point confirmed.The film slips up on other levels. Isla Fisher, the delightful actress from "Wedding Crashers" who got a deserved MTV movie award for her performance, isn't wearing her game face, instead relying on tired love interest cliches; her work isn't bad, just rather disappointing (things will be a different story in "Wedding Daze", which even recalls her goofy laugh from "WC"). Though Will Arnett has a couple good lines (believe me, Amy Poehler's hubby isn't that bad a comic actor, he just needs direction), his role seemed inconsequential, and deserved more screen time than Schaffer gives him. Same goes for Sissy Spacek, who doesn't make much of a mark.I don't necessarily hate the film. I'm just a little disappointed that even with all the hard work the movie boasts, and the hype behind this movie, it isn't funnier than it should've been. Samberg does a good job, even though his winks can stop the film dead (think of what Bobby Lee does on "MadTV"), and his wonder of who could be better - a grilled cheese sandwich or a taco - allows him to channel an old-school Adam Sandler that I'm sure Sandler couldn't dare touch these days. That's fine with me.

reviewText: Rod Kimble is a goofy, wannabe stuntman in the style of Evel Knievel who rides around town on his moped with his crew of 3 attempting dangerous but small-scale stunts and failing miserably. All he thinks about is becoming a famous stuntman like his deceased father and earning the respect of his step-dad, Frank, with whom he regularly battles in the most literal sense. Rod's world gets shaken up though when he discovers that Frank needs expensive heart surgery and could die before Rod is able to beat him in a fight and prove that he's a man. Luckily, Rod's beautiful neighbor Denise has returned to town just in time to help with his plan to raise the money for Frank's surgery by doing a huge stunt. Unfortunately, Denise has brought her sleazy boyfriend Jonathan with her. It's all great fun as Rod and his group of local yokels, along with the drop-dead-gorgeous Denise, attempt to train and raise money for the big day and deal with some difficulties and tragedies along the way. And even if the gang is successful at raising the money to put on their big stunt, jumping 15 school buses (one more than Evel Knievel), Rod will still have to pull it off without getting killed!"Hot Rod" is easily one of the best comedies I've ever seen and certainly better than the much praised (but really just average) "Superbad". It's got a lot more heart too. Starring hilarious SNL cast member Andy Samberg as Rod and the adorable Isla Fisher (looking more gorgeous than I've ever seen her and in some really cute outfits; love the way she looks in a ponytail and a T-shirt) as Denise, the whole cast is a real treat and the music (much from glam-metal group "Europe") is out of this world. Though the film is set in modern-day, there's a delightful 1980's nostalgia throughout (though without the bad stuff like girls with '80's hair; it's more like nostalgia for folks like me who were really little in the '80's). If you enjoy simple-minded, lighthearted comedy like the Blue Collar guys or an Ernest movie, got a kick out of "Kickin' It Old School", and felt "Napoleon Dynamite", "Nacho Libre", and "Elf" were some of the funniest movies you've seen in a long time, you're really gonna love this one! The standard DVD is outstanding too. The film is in widescreen and looks and sounds great, and there are a ton of extras! There's a fun commentary with Andy Samberg, Jorma Taccone (who plays Rod's brother), and director Akiva Schaffer, some great outtakes and deleted scenes with optional commentary, a trailer, a behind the scenes featurette, a look at recording music for the film, and a neat comparison of the film's "punch dancing" sequence with the scene in "Footloose" that inspired it. Awesome movie and a great DVD, highly recommended!
summary: Prepare for one of the funniest films you've ever seen!

reviewText: This movie almost slipped my radar. I happened to watch it only because I had absolutely nothing left to do and I enjoyed Andy's work on SNL. I expected nothing. What I got in return was 88 minutes of pure comedy.If you don't like "silly" humor intertwined with a somewhat weak plot, then this movie is not for you.The film reminds me of previous films by SNL star Adam Sandler. The protagonist is a borderline special-needs kid who somehow not only manages to function, but also accomplishes unrealistic feats. In addition, he somehow manages to attract the attention of a beautiful girl who has a jerk of a boyfriend.It's better than some of Sandler's comedies because we're not forced to endure a silly voice coupled with a stupid expression plastered on our hero's face.Instead, we're given Rod, a hapless child who yearns deeply for the respect of his step-father and will go through whatever means necessary to obtain it.For most of the movie, if I didn't have a smile on my face, I was laughing out loud.There is one scene where SNL veteran Chris Parnell describes a tattoo of his that looks unrealistic but his explanation gives it just enough of hint of truth to make it absurdly funny.Viewers who appreciate TheLonelyIsland's work (one of Adam's comedy troops) will also appreciate many scenes in this movie. There is also a scene which pays homage to song-montages from 80s movies. If you haven't seen this movie and are looking to laugh, I say watch it. It's really funny!Cool beans!
summary: Strap-in and get ready to laugh.

reviewText: Andy Samberg does not have a natural comedian talent, and trying hard in this regard does not make things better, or does it? Perhaps to them who think Adam Sandler is a talented comedian, Andy may appear funny ha-ha, sort of Sandler-lite."Hot Rod" tries to be a nutty-witty sort of comedy with noticeable attempts at "witty" and sometimes "nutty." However, its plot and gags are way too predictable for "nutty," while some "funnies" go on for too long, or repeat too many times for "witty." It will leave you with unpleasant aftertaste-like musing: "and that's all??"Not recommended. I rate it an extra star for avoiding profane language and for the lack of anti-Christian sacrilege, which has become obligatory in almost every new Hollywood production.

reviewText: For a fun, mindless and relaxing good time, check out "Hot Rod," one of those goofy, lowest-common-denominator slapstick comedies which won't do much to raise your IQ or make you a better person for having seen it, but which just might put a smile on your face - provided you're not too highbrow to give yourself over to it, that is.Prime credit for the movie's success goes to SNL's powerhouse-of-energy Andy Sandberg, an immensely gifted physical comedian who doesn't get nearly the recognition he deserves for his talents.  Here he plays Rod Kimble, a developmentally-challenged wannabe daredevil who fancies himself the heir apparent to none other than the late great Evel Knievel himself.  To that end, Rod devises elaborate stunts - usually involving jumping over large objects or a series of large objects on his secondhand moped - that invariably lead to his winding up face down in the dirt or smashed headlong into some massive immovable object.  But you just can't keep a good stuntman down and, after every fall, Rod picks himself up, dusts himself off and, disregarding his bruised body and bruised ego, heads on to his next venture, eternally optimistic that this time he will be able to complete his mission.  Rod's goal is to impress not only the pretty girl who lives next door (Isla Fisher) but his mucho macho step dad (Ian McShane) who thinks Rod is just a mollycoddled, cape-wearing pantywaist, undeserving of his respect.Joining in the fun are fellow SNL stars, Bill Hader and Chris Parnell, along with "Arrested Development"'s Will Arnett and acting legend Sissy Spacek to class up the joint.Replete with corny `80s-style musical montage sequences and some mighty impressive stunt work, "Hot Rod" will win you over with its good-natured dopiness and charm.  And the good feeling that it engenders may even be worth those couple of brain cells you'll lose in the course of watching it.

reviewText: Hot Rod (Andy Samberg) would love to follow in the footsteps of his deceased father, a former stunt man who worked closely with Evel Knievel. He is really much to old to be practicing childish stunts unsuccessfully, but when he learns that his step-father (Ian McShane) needs a heart transplant the family cannot afford, he decides to take his career ambitions seriously to raise money for the operation. Along with his crew (Jorma Taccone, Bill Hader, Danny R. McBride, and Isla Fisher), he devises an insane plot to bring his step-father back to full health, and simply so he can beat him up to prove that he is indeed a man.The trailers for this movie are decieving. They depict tired jokes and a lame plot. They give the wrong impression, because this movie is packed with hilarious moments. The plot doesn't matter at all; the humor comes from the randomness of the scenes and the goofyness of Rod. The character is similar to Napoleon Dynamite but the humor is much more obvious. Samberg has to be one of the funniest comedians to hit SNL for a long time. His brand of humor is very fresh and relevant to the current generation.Furthermore, the extra features on the DVD are very funny. The making-of featurette shows the cast and crew joking around with each other. Some of the deleted scenes are hilarious, and seeing Rod's punch dance alongside Kevin Bacon's in Footloose is a delight.From "Hey, Rod, what's that song about a grandma getting run over by a reindeer?" to "I need to go to my quiet place!", you'll find yourself quoting this movie constantly. It is just that funny.
summary: "He won't be smiling WHEN I MURDER HIM!"

reviewText: 2007 brought us a handful of new screwball comedies ( Superbad, Knocked Up, Blades of Glory, Walk Hard...and the list goes on and on ) in the same genre as HOT ROD, and for whatever reason HOT ROD fell off to the way-side.  Starring the lovable Andy Samberg, adorable Jorma Taccone, Isla Fisher, Bill Hader annnndd Danny McBride.  (Not to mention hilarious roles played by Will Arnett and Chris Parnell.)Directed by Akiva Schaffer, the third member of 'The Lonely Island' comedy team (with Andy Samberg and Jorma Taccone) HOT ROD somehow brings something more to the table then the rest.  Maybe it is their close friendship that made it all come together so perfectly?Rod Kimble is a lovable Jack-of-all-trades who has a heart of gold in everything he does, even when it comes to his desire to beat his stepfather in order for his respect. There's nothing he can't accomplish with the help of his crew. (They like to party!)Scene after scene is hilarious. Kevin singing in his room to his stuffed animals, the grilled cheese versus taco death match, or jumping his bike straight into the community pool.The soundtrack also compliments the movie perfectly. Half of the tracks supplied by Europe in their 80's power-ballad-awesomeness, with some quotes sprinkled in. Not to mention 'You're the Voice' by John Farnham, which will always remind me of the classic scene in the film.Although it's humor is not for everyone, I suggest giving it a real try. If nothing more it will give you a new song to sing next time you're going on a date!"When you're going on a date, put on a shirt and you drive your bike to the date!"  Oh Rod!
summary: Too Legit To Quit - The Story of a Stuntman

reviewText: This MIGHT not be the worst movie I've ever seen, but it is definitely in my top five for all-time worst!  I wasn't expecting anything deep, but it would have been nice if it wasn't just so stupid!  Sissy Spacek is MUCH too good for this. I was disappointed to see her talent wasted on this dreck.  It's not even funny when it tries to be, and come on - when he falls down the side of a mountain, he's barely even hurt?  give me a break.  Don't waste your time on this. it's TERRIBLE.
summary: How many ways can you say stupid?
Title: N/A

reviewText: `Hot Rod' is a hilarious comedy with the best cheesy eighties soundtrack you will ever hear. Following a teenage stuntman who plans to jump 15 buses to raise 50k for his stepfathers heart operation, this film has many laugh out loud moments and reminded me of `Waynes World' for it's outlandish fantasies and shameless homage to all things geeky and kitsch. Everyone plays their roles perfectly and the deadpan delivery of some lines and the completely off the wall touches had me laughing out loud at various points throughout the film. The punch dance is a particular highlight and there is an feature on the extras showing the filming of this scene. The eighties power ballads really added to the overall feel of the film and although extremely cheesy, fit perfectly with the characters and story, who isn't inspired by an eighties rock song behind a stunt sequence eh! This is short at just over 80 minutes but it achieves what it sets out to and is a light hearted, fun, off the wall comedy. I didn't expect to enjoy it as much as I did and this makes for great viewing.Feel free to check out my blog which can be found on my profile page.

reviewText: Quick summary: do not waste your time on THIS movie.  I could end this review here, but I'll go on with some details just in case you really want to know why I say that.You are still reading this?!  What, do you have relatives that worked on this crap fest or are you just a glutton for punishment?!?!  Well, here goes.  First, would whoever is responsible for keeping Lorne Michaels and the crew of weak-talents at SNL away from making movies please go out and round up all of the copies of Hot Rod that were released so they can be destroyed and put us all out of our misery?!? (While they are out there they could likely round up a bunch of other bad movies by Michaels with his SNL friends at the same time...)What a waste of HD DVD disc materials and other resources.  I chuckled a few times at this movie, but really it's been a while since I've seen anything that bad.  Perhaps back to the Norbit time frame.  Horribly bad.Sissy Spacek and Ian McShane (whom I really like as an actor and would normally give the benefit of the doubt to) should be ashamed of wasting their talent on this sort of crap.  I guess this movie is part of why Spacek did a recent Hallmark Hall of Fame TV movie -- it's penance for this piece of trash.If you really want to see this movie, consider Unbox on Amazon or some other rental method so you won't be sorry later that you actually bought a copy.  Even if the price was dramatically discounted, I couldn't justify spending money on buying it (I would say that someone would have to pay me a king's ransom if they wanted me to buy and keep this thing, and even then I would probably eject it from my collection as soon as any contractual obligation to keep it would be gone).Suffice it to say that I want the 90 minutes plus that I wasted on watching this pathetically boring and bad movie back.I suppose I should have known well enough in advance.  The reviews weren't great, the movie didn't take in that much money at the box office, and yes, it was a Lorne Michaels movie with SNL alums in the major roles.  That would be what some people call a clue.  Well, I figured it couldn't be all that bad.  No, it wasn't all that bad -- it was worse.  It was lame.  I've seen bad, and then again I've seen bad.  This was at the lowest end of the scale.
summary: Do not waste your time watching this movie.

reviewText: Wretched as a word that seems to make a lot of other folks laugh??? Do you even know what you're renting when you pick it up at the store??? Wretched??????For the folks that want to put this movie down because it's stupid, creates a bad image of today's youth, or doesn't include whatever type of sniveling crap they want to consider as pertinent to being a kid ... then you've really missed the point.And what happened to your man sack, did Oprah tell you it was a bad idea to have one?????Hot Rod is a movie that is meant to make you laugh, plain and simple. it could be likened to a skit from SNL. basically the writers try to come up with lines, ideas, or situations which will be as funny to what they imagine the viewing audience might be. with most movies; this one included, the desired demographic are young males with either no girlfriend, one that will let them go see this with their friends, or a girl that would laugh at this kind of humor.and for you young single guys out there, if you ever find a gal who likes the "Holy Grail" as much as you do ... marry her right then and there!!!!)we live in a day where hardly anyone rights a "comedy" without trying to shove some kind of moral down your throat. a comedy should be funny like the classics (ie airplane, blazing saddles, the holy grail, the exorcist, schindler's list, million dollar baby...anyway take the stick, corncob, or whatever it is out of your butt and have a laugh!!! God knows we need it in a world where everyday we see stories about our neighbors and youth getting blown up by some idiot in some piece of crap sand pit that killed 3000+ of our countrymen first!!!!!!!and by the way if we can't laugh at retards and idiots, then who's left???o yeah, those condescending jerks that think they know what's best for everyone else!!!!!!!!!!!!!God Bless America
summary: Wretched? ... you've reeeeeealy been watching to many pirate movies

reviewText: Easily reaching new heights of absurdity, Akiva Schaffer's debut comedy Hot Rod blends ridiculous slapstick, obnoxious antics, and random outbursts of genius, though much less of the latter. Moving into done-before plot territory, but counteracting such familiarity with heavy visual comedy and inserted lunacy of a repetitively jarring nature, Hot Rod seems destined to jump only half of the school buses it sets out to.Rod Kimble (Andy Samberg) is driven to be a great stuntman by the legend of his deceased real father and the burning desire to be respected by his stepfather Frank (Ian McShane). When Frank falls fatally ill with the only viable cure being a 50,000 dollar heart transplant, Rod and his team of misfit colleagues, joined by childhood friend and love interest Denise (Isla Fisher), determine to perform a harrowing stunt to raise the money.So many ideas of comedic direction surface in the former SNL collaborators' film that the few truly creative ones get bogged down by the influx of ill-conceived opposites. For every unexpectedly clever farce, two ridiculously immature concepts rise up to drown out the brief moments of ingenuity. The slapstick throughout works as intended, but parallels an oft-repeated style of repetitive silliness that can only go so far before becoming tiring to the senses. Several segments such as the "quiet place" scene and the team member introduction to Denise offer a fresh take on repetition, but by the time "cool beans" rolls around we're not so impressed. The most original aspect of Hot Rod's humor comes from the extreme randomness of certain snippets of dialogue and unrelated inserts that neither serve to enhance the story nor relate to the proceedings they interrupt. Pitting personified grilled cheese sandwiches against tacos, singing to stuffed animals, and inspirational marches turned rioting in the streets mark some of the highlights of the bizarre inventions unsystematically imbedded for quick laughs and shock value. As the film progresses it's hard to wipe the smirk from your face (unless you abhor immaturity), but too seldom is the urge to laugh out loud presented.The acting matches the movie's humor and while Samberg clearly gets the best lines, every so often one of the supporting characters will steal some spotlight. Co-creator and actor Jorma Taccone plays off the lead's childishness quite admirably and Isla Fisher provides a few scenes of slapstick assistance and verbal mockery, though mostly she just lends her sex appeal. If you attempt to focus on more than that you'll notice her Australian accent slipping through her speeches. The other two members of Rod's crew rarely offer anything in addition to what's expected of their imbecilic characters and any physical comedy performed is out staged by the more charismatic Samberg. Anyone younger than the film's stars will likely find amusement in the overly immature parody, but those seeking intelligent humor should look elsewhere.The darker wit and deep irony that juxtapose the asinine laughs in blockbuster comedies like Wedding Crashers or Old School is unfortunately absent in Hot Rod, and no moral fiber resides underneath the physical spectacles and horseplay. We care little for the well-being or success of the protagonists because their motives seem empty in comparison to those of the aforementioned comedies. Without fully fleshed-out characters the trials and tribulations they undergo feel weightless and insignificant, and we're left to bond with the juvenile jocosity, a task not easily accomplished by the intellectually proficient.Hot Rod starts painfully bizarre, progresses with sporadic random comedy, and concludes with resonating immature slapstick. While all of these elements provide a profound impact on the overall presentation of the film, they rarely mesh to form anything truly innovative or unexpected from the genre. What works does so surprisingly well, but unfortunately too often the movie makes us feel as if we've stumbled into the middle of a joke, and no matter how funny the punch line is, it's only half as effective as hearing the whole thing. To lower a pun to an equivalent level of maturity, I'd have to say that this Hot Rod cools off and pulls out too quickly before we're fully satisfied.- Joel Massie

reviewText: There are two types of comedies, the ones that make you laugh because they are so funny and the ones that are clever and make you feel warm and fuzzy.  Hot Rod is neither, instead it falls into my category of how did this film ever get made?  I did not laugh once during the length of the film (a meager 90 minutes), nor did I smile, grin or for that matter show any emotion until the movie was FINALLY over.The plot is basic enough a nerdy guy does not realize that he is a dork as he tries to perform stunts using his moped.  Granted the moped is not even tricked out so every stunt is doomed to fail.  However Rod (the main character) is cheered on by his crew of even bigger nerds.  Than comes the love interest the really hot neighbor who is really into Rod (even though she has been off to college and exposed to real men), to get Rods interest she joins the crew.  Rod must make one big stunt so he can pay for his step dads heart transplant.  The step dad does not respect Rod and Rod can only gain his respect by beating him in a fight.  Thus step dad must live so they can fight one more time for respect.  This is it in a nutshell.In my opinion this movie ranks as one of the lamest movies ever made.
summary: Not sure how this movie got so many positive reviews.

reviewText: This reviewer likes Andy Samberg on SNL.  He has become very versatile taking on what this reviewer would consider the man-child persona Adam Sandler began on SNL, handing it next to Jimmy Fallon and now to Adam Sandberg. However, HOT ROD is not the vehicle to push Samberg into any higher stratosphere of comedic lore. This is one of the worst movies this reviewer has seen in a long time. Very painful to watch and very painful to sit through. It has no redeeming comedic qualities whatsoever.  One could understand casting some of Samberg's SNL castmates in the film. However, how the heck did [they] get the likes of Sissy Spacek and Ian McShane to round out the cast? Samberg  plays Rod Kimble, a loser who wants to be a stuntman and the next Evel Knievel. However, instead of stunts on a motorcycle, he can only afford a moped to do his stunts. Then, when his stepfather becomes ill, he wants to use his skills to do a big jump to raise money for his step dad's medical bills. The rest the film shows Rod (Samberg) training and preparing for the big jump with some painful and not-so-funny mishaps. The script istelf has some jarring and inconsequential dialogue some of which doesn't make sense. Overall, not a very auspicious start of a film career for another SNL alumni
summary: Hot Rod Spins Out of Control
